slides.title: Business requirement
slides.ocrText:
| Business requirement

Arranging and monitoring services is a large part of
adjudicating claims. | need to way to track what
services are needed and used on a claim. One way to
make sure we are managing services well is to track

the performance of vendors that we recommend to
our insured.

Tanvi \foas
Adjuster “Wa

Y

slides.title: Vendor services
slides.originalNotes:
Vendor services
Vendor services help identify the right vendors for a given incident or claim. The adjuster can search for and assign work, or services, to a specific vendor Once a service is assigned to a vendor, the adjuster can manage and follow services on a claim from the inception of the service request to completion of the work and payment for the service. A claims adjuster may request a quote, services only, or both.

A history of all service requests, whether they are in progress, or completed, is available from the Services screen on a claim.

The Vendor tag on the vendor in Contact Manager determines whether the contact is an identifiable ClaimCenter vendor. An important distinction is that the Vendor tag, not the contact type, distinguishes vendors from other contacts in Contact Manager. This is because a service vendor may be either a company or a person.
slides.notes:

This is because a service vendor may be either a company or a person.

| Vendor services i

slides.title: Service request scenario
slides.originalNotes:
Service request scenario
Assigning a vendor to a claim can occur at the initial intake of the claim or later. When a user adds a service to a claim, they can select one of 3 different request types. It can be to perform the service if the type of service would not require a quote. It can be for a quote only, or it can be to provide a quote and perform the service. The quote and perform service request is for a full- service lifecycle, including a record of the quote documents and estimates and service work.
slides.notes:
Service request scenario
Assigning a vendor to a claim can occur at the initial intake of the claim or later. When a user adds a service to a claim, they can select one of 3 different request types. It can be to perform the service if the type of service would not require a quote. It can be for a quote only, or it can be to provide a quote and perform the service. The quote and perform service request is for a full- service lifecycle, including a record of the quote documents and estimates and service work.
slides.ocrText:
| Service request scenario G&G

* Service creation can occur at claim creation or later
« ACSR or adjuster searches ContactManager for an appropriate vendor

* The service request can be for a quote only, perform service only, or a quote and
perform service

slides.title: Possible vendor responses
slides.originalNotes:
Possible vendor responses
When a request is sent to a vendor, there are several possible responses. The vendor may agree to provide a quote and may provide that quote either through a vendor portal, or directly to the adjuster. They may also decline a request, for whatever reason, or they may accept the request with a specific time frame extension.
slides.notes:
Possible vendor responses
When a request is sent to a vendor, there are several possible responses. The vendor may agree to provide a quote and may provide that quote either through a vendor portal, or directly to the adjuster. They may also decline a request, for whatever reason, or they may accept the request with a specific time frame extension.

slides.title: Adding a service to a claim: New Claim Wizard fa
slides.originalNotes:
Adding a service to a claim: New Claim Wizard
In the New Claim Wizard, there are two ways to add services. The first is on the incident details screen. In this example, the incident is a vehicle. The user can add details and select services for the incident. Any details required for adding the service must be entered while adding the service. For example, if an autobody repair service is added, the user must find and select a repair shop for the service as well as provide the service address.

The New Claim Wizard also has a step that is dedicated to Vendor Services. This screen behaves just like the incident details Screen
slides.notes:
Adding a service to a claim: New Claim Wizard
In the New Claim Wizard, there are two ways to add services. The first is on the incident details screen. In this example, the incident is a vehicle. The user can add details and select services for the incident. Any details required for adding the service must be entered while adding the service. For example, if an autobody repair service is added, the user must find and select a repair shop for the service as well as provide the service address.

The New Claim Wizard also has a step that is dedicated to Vendor Services. This screen behaves just like the incident details Screen

slides.title: Adding a service to a claim: Claim page
slides.originalNotes:
Adding a service to a claim: Claim page
You can add services to a claim anytime in the lifecycle of a claim. From the Actions menu, select New Service. The Add Service screen allows you to select either the claim or incident the service is related to. Just like in the New Claim Wizard, the user selects the type of request, quote, perform, or quote and perform, the vendor and the service address.
slides.notes:
Adding a service to a claim: Claim page
You can add services to a claim anytime in the lifecycle of a claim. From the Actions menu, select New Service. The Add Service screen allows you to select either the claim or incident the service is related to. Just like in the New Claim Wizard, the user selects the type of request, quote, perform, or quote and perform, the vendor and the service address.

slides.title: Service metrics
slides.originalNotes:
Service metrics
Assigned services provide a way to track vendor performance over time. When the vendor is assigned to perform a service, ClaimCenter collects metrics for evaluating the vendor performance for the request. The metrics include quote timeliness, response time, service timeliness, and invoice vs quote variance.

Quote only service requests, do not measure service timelines or invoice variances.
slides.notes:
Service metrics
Assigned services provide a way to track vendor performance over time. When the vendor is assigned to perform a service, ClaimCenter collects metrics for evaluating the vendor performance for the request. The metrics include quote timeliness, response time, service timeliness, and invoice vs quote variance.

Quote only service requests, do not measure service timelines or invoice variances.

slides.title: Lifecycle of a service
slides.originalNotes:
Lifecycle of a service
Service request lifecycles differ slightly depending on the type of request. For example a quote only service focuses on receiving the quote in a timely manner rather than managing and tracking the work. The lifecycle for a quote and perform service includes everything from the inception of the request to
payment for the service.
That full lifecycle starts with the creation of the service request followed by the vendor either accepting, declining, or delaying the quote. Once the vendor accepts the request, the next step is to receive and approve the quote.
In a quote and perform service, the service can only be marked as complete after the quote has been received and approved. Once the service is marked as complete and there is an invoice, ClaimCenter may automatically create a payment. This payment is dependent on an existing reserve and limits configured in Straight Through Invoice Processing, or STIP. The base application has a defined limit of $500.
slides.notes:
Lifecycle of a service
Service request lifecycles differ slightly depending on the type of request. For example a quote only service focuses on receiving the quote in a timely manner rather than managing and tracking the work. The lifecycle for a quote and perform service includes everything from the inception of the request to
payment for the service.
That full lifecycle starts with the creation of the service request followed by the vendor either accepting, declining, or delaying the quote. Once the vendor accepts the request, the next step is to receive and approve the quote.
In a quote and perform service, the service can only be marked as complete after the quote has been received and approved. Once the service is marked as complete and there is an invoice, ClaimCenter may automatically create a payment. This payment is dependent on an existing reserve and limits configured in Straight Through Invoice Processing, or STIP. The base application has a defined limit of $500.

slides.title: Vendor progress: Vendor Claim Portal fa
slides.originalNotes:
Vendor progress: Vendor Claim Portal
When a quote only vendor service request is sent to the vendor through a portal, the vendor sees the service request and has a choice of actions. They can choose Accept Work, Add Quote or Decline Work. In this example, the vendor accepts the work and gives a date by which they expect to send the quote. Entering this date gives the claims adjuster an idea of when to expect a reply from the vendor, and also provides data that helps evaluate the vendor's timeliness and performance.

Notice the information from ClaimCenter which includes the type of service requested, the ID which is the equivalent of the Claim number, and the Next Step being equivalent to the Next Action in ClaimCenter.

Use of a vendor portal gives adjusters the ability to easily communicate with service providers directly and move through the service request lifecycle. Quotes, invoices and progress milestones such as Vendor Accepted Work, Vendor Completed Quote and so on, are recorded by interaction with a portal.
slides.notes:
Vendor progress: Vendor Claim Portal
When a quote only vendor service request is sent to the vendor through a portal, the vendor sees the service request and has a choice of actions. They can choose Accept Work, Add Quote or Decline Work. In this example, the vendor accepts the work and gives a date by which they expect to send the quote. Entering this date gives the claims adjuster an idea of when to expect a reply from the vendor, and also provides data that helps evaluate the vendor's timeliness and performance.

Notice the information from ClaimCenter which includes the type of service requested, the ID which is the equivalent of the Claim number, and the Next Step being equivalent to the Next Action in ClaimCenter.

Use of a vendor portal gives adjusters the ability to easily communicate with service providers directly and move through the service request lifecycle. Quotes, invoices and progress milestones such as Vendor Accepted Work, Vendor Completed Quote and so on, are recorded by interaction with a portal.

| Vendor progress: Vendor Claim Portal fa

• Vendor can accept or decline work, add a quote, provide status updates, and
submit invoices

slides.title: Vendor progress: without Vendor Claim Portal
slides.originalNotes:
Vendor progress: without Vendor Claim Portal
When a vendor does not have access to the vendor portal, the CSR or adjuster manually records progress for the service. The data collected and maintained is the same. The only difference is how the information is recorded. Without using the vendor portal, the vendor contacts the adjuster to update the status of the service. Those updates can include acceptance of the service request, submission of a quote, or even completion of the service.
slides.notes:
Vendor progress: without Vendor Claim Portal
When a vendor does not have access to the vendor portal, the CSR or adjuster manually records progress for the service. The data collected and maintained is the same. The only difference is how the information is recorded. Without using the vendor portal, the vendor contacts the adjuster to update the status of the service. Those updates can include acceptance of the service request, submission of a quote, or even completion of the service.

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What different types of requests can an adjuster make on a service
• request?
•
•

questionData.question: What different types of requests can an adjuster make on a service request?
questionData.answer: Perform Service, Quote, Quote and Perform service.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What different types of requests can an adjuster make on a service
request?
“ Perform Service, Quote, Quote and Perform service.
Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
What is one thing that will prevent a service from being marked
completed?

questionData.question: What is one thing that will prevent a service from being marked completed?
questionData.answer: If a service is a Quote and Perform Service request, it cannot be marked complete until after the quote is received and approved.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
What is one thing that will prevent a service from being marked
completed?
If a service is a Quote and Perform Service request, it cannot be marked complete
until after the quote is received and approved.
Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD

slides.title: Knowledge Check
slides.ocrText:
Question
When can an invoice be automatically paid?
•
•

questionData.question: When can an invoice be automatically paid?
questionData.answer: When an invoice is entered for a service that is marked complete and there is a matching reserve line.

slides.title: Answer
slides.ocrText:
Answer
When can an invoice be automatically paid?
•
When an invoice is entered for a service that is marked complete and there is a
matching reserve line.
Sooo ooo ooo Oooo oOoD
